Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a lot about Calculus but I don't feel that I have a great depth of knowledge or that most of the things I learned will help me in future math.
Calc ab pretty much
I learned all of the fundamentals of calculus. You will finish the course KNOWING calculus, although really complex problems may still be a challenge.
I learned how to differentiate and integrate.

This course gave me more insight into the methods and applications of calculus, with discussions of the use of calculus in the real world. The course encouraged me to appreciate mathematical theory alongside the actual calculations, which is something that I hadn't experienced prior to taking this course.

Even though I already took calc in high school, this class made my understanding much more solid and was amazing to be taking at the same time as physics. Things like the basics of diff eqs and optimization became more clear to me because of this class and were very applicable.
I learned a necessary introduction to calculus, beginning with limits through beginning integrals.
I know have a deep understanding of calculus.
I learned most properties of integration.
Great introduction to all you need about differentiation, or a great review of it
I learned the fundamental concepts of calculus.
lots and lots of math, mainly limits and derivatives. how to break down problems.
I expanded knowledge on calculus. Many of the lessons learned were on how to apply previously understood concepts to more difficult settings/ problems.
Knowledge of calculus; taking limits, derivatives, and the meaning of both in relation to real world problems.
I learned the first term content for single-variable calculus. I improved on skills I learned in AP Calculus AB.
My knowledge of calculus and skill in non-calculator mathematics.
I didn't develop any insights by taking this course.
The course should focus more on important topics and drop some less important topics.
weakness: chalk boards. powerpoint slides would be much more efficient.
The course is great for helping students learn. Frequent assignments sometimes piled up, but peer tutors were an excellent resource to get homework help.
Very informative, but the midterm questions were awkwardly weighted (T/F questions made up a significant portion).

The course encourages group learning and collaborative working with peers, which can be very helpful but also can lead to some uncertainty. Completing exercises in class with peers was a great way to understand and apply concepts; however, I often felt that the difficulty of the problems covered in class was not representative of the difficulty of the problems on the P-Sets and the WebAssign, which (although expected) often made the homework rather laborious.

I like the class sizes, which allow for a personal relationship with the teacher. I wish I had been told before the class started that we get an online book included when we buy web assign because I wouldnt have bought the hard copy.
It was a lot of work, and the problem sets that took me probably about six hours a week to complete, had very limited similarity to the actual exam.
Have WebAssign be counted for completion.
The strengths were the psets and the in class worksheets. The weaknesses were the webassign assignments.
This course would be better if the worksheets are created to match more closely with the exam questions.

I felt that the quality of the course varied on who was teaching it. There were sections that seemed to well taught and others that were not at all. I also found the textbook/ webassign homework system used to be incredibly inefficient and over priced. The software costs $100 dollars. There are other homework systems that work far better for far less.

Pam was such a great instructor. It was extremely clear from the start that she cared about her students and their learning. I loved how engaging her class was and how helpful she is, in and out of the classroom.

The first problem set focused too much on pre-calculus material, which seemed to scare a lot of people into dropping to Math 110 even though that material didn't drastically affect my ability to take the course.

The strengths of this course was the pace at which the content was taught. The weaknesses are the psets. They have questions beyond the scope of the course and this gives the students the mindset of 'trying to complete the pset (by going to peer tutoring)' rather than 'trying to practice the concepts through doing the pset'.
The amount of homework is a weakness. Doing both a Pset and 2 web assigns per week was a much greater work load than my other courses, and the webassigns were rarely helpful

This class taught things in the weirdest way. I had prior knowledge in calculus, but I know a lot of people who didn't. A lot of the concepts went over would be really difficult to learn if you weren't in calculus your high school years. Even then, the course would teach things already touched upon in high school calculus. However, the way and order that it had to be taught in were more like a big review instead of an actual teaching.
I really loved my professor but greatly disliked the class and the use of WebAssign. Our grader was extremely harsh and it was unfair for much of what we got docked for.
yes! great if you do not want to throw yourself in the water with math 115.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I especially recommend Pam if you can get her as your instructor. She is very helpful and always available for students who need help. She also explains concepts remarkably clearly, which is invaluable in a math class.
Yes! If you need to touch up on Calculus or have forgotten much of your math, this is a good course to take to refresh.
Absolutely! I already have, for several people. But only if they have Pam as the professor.
I would recommend it because of the necessity of the content in other STEM areas of Yale college, but if you don't need it, don't take it.
I would recommend this course.
I would because it helped me learn the properties of calculus.
Yes! Pam taught the class very well, with an attention to us as individuals, not just students. Very understanding and takes time to clarify on tricky subjects
Yes, this is a great course for a student interested in learning the fundamentals of calculus.
if you need to take math, and are in calc 1 take it, its a good course.

If you are a student looking for a QR credit, I would suggest taking another course. There are many other QRs that are much more well structured and easier than this. However, if you want to review the underlying principals of calculus I would recommend the course. I you are new to calculus this course will be challenging as the pace is incredibly fast. Many of the students in my class had already taken calculus in high school. Only two people had never seen the content before.
Yes!! But only if you have it with Pam, I'm not sure about the other professors.

Yes, it is a good class. I understood calculus for the first time. Despite learning a good amount of the material in high school, I finally understood how it all relates to each other (for example, a derivative is the slope of the tangent line at a point).
I would recommend this course if it was a prerequisite or if the student enjoyed learning calculus.
As a basis of calculus it is necessary to take this course, but as a course itself I wouldnt recommend it.
I would recommend this course to another student if they were debating whether they're not interested in math or whether math was just challenging for them.
